title: [K-12] Simulation-Based Visual Display System Design

context.prior_knowledge: Foundational mathematics (linear algebra, geometry), basic programming concepts, and introduction to computer graphics
context.additional_context: Project-based activity in a digital device-provided environment, involving team-based simulation design and implementation of visual output systems.

learning_goals: Learners derive simulation requirements by applying a 3-tier visual display classification system reflecting human visual-cognitive characteristics

Learners can compare specifications of three display components (monitor, graphics card, cables) within a given budget (e.g., $500) and select an optimal combination meeting two or more of the evaluation criteria (resolution, performance-to-price ratio, compatibility).

Learners can develop a simple simulation prototype (e.g., game, physics phenomenon model) applying real-world mathematical modeling (e.g., linear equations, probability distributions) in Python or Scratch within one week and submit a result meeting three or more of the five teacher-provided evaluation criteria (functionality, creativity, accuracy, completeness, documentation).
difficulty: Easy - Simple structure with minimal constraints
